name: Ireland And The Cinema
description:
Learning Outcomes:
This course will enable students to:

• synthesise their knowledge within economic industrial aesthetic and socio-cultural contexts

• be conversant with the historical political and social backgrounds to these works

• evaluate the shifting nature of film representation in the periods covered

• apply the critical approaches under discussion to specific films

 
Module Learning Aims:
Rationale and Aims:

This is a Senior Freshman core course. This course will explore the history

and contemporary context of Irish cinema as well as key representations of

Ireland and the Irish in world cinema.

Methods of Teaching and Student Learning:

This course will be taught through a combination of film screenings lectures

and seminars. Students will be expected to prepare for seminar discussion by

reading the set texts and viewing the set film.
Module Content:
Course Content:

‘Ireland and the Cinema’ will take a critical and historical look at Irish cinema. It will commence with the two foundation films that have determined representations of the Irish (Man of Aran & The Quiet Man) before proceeding to themes and issues within Irish cinema. These will include: the Troubles; history; gender; the Celtic Tiger and post-Celtic Tiger cinema. It will cover documentaries and animation as well as live-action films.

name: Applied Directing
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students should be able to:

extend and expand upon skills and concepts addressed in Principles of Directing with regard to a directorial concept based on a dramatic text

visualise and bring to embodiment a vision for set costume and props as supports the text and concept

work with a technician to add orchestration of LX and FX signification to a dramatic piece of 20 minutes in length

conceive and effect scene-to-scene transition


 
Module Learning Aims:
This is the second module of a three-part cycle designed to equip students with the skills of the theatre director. After six weeks of laboratory classes exploring aspects of the directing process through problem-based learning students will prepare an individual project. This course aims to provide a fundamental grounding for directors from which they can go on to engage with different approaches and theories of directing.

 
Module Content:
Available 2012/2013 This module has three phrases: a large group project on Shakespeare texts linked with Advanced Design courses numerous small problem-based assignments in class and the twenty-minute scene from a text of the student’s own choosing (presented in Week 10 of the module) subject to approval by the course lecturer. Throughout the module students should be prepared to present work and to comment critically upon each other’s work. Each workshop session is designed to bring students into contact with at least one practical challenge or conceptual problem of directing preparing students to navigate imposed difficulties or restrictions in the live theatre. The teaching approach will thus be problem-based in which students must work in both group and solo contexts to resolve imposed obstacles and meet an objective. Outside reading research rehearsal and meetings will be required in addition to the two hours of weekly class. The classes will augment work done in Principles of Directing by bringing in elements of design and building interpersonal communication skills with actors and collaborators

A series of lectures and public interviews with practitioners will form the basis of the weekly schedule.

name: Lighting Design
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students should be able to:

 
·     demonstrate knowledge of the principles of electricity optics light sources and lanterns

·     demonstrate knowledge of control systems computer-aided design colour and special effects

·     demonstrate an awareness of light and its communicating potential in visual culture

·     conceive and execute scale drawing and the realisation of a lighting plan based on a dramatic text

·     conceive and realise a lighting design for a theatre production


 
Module Learning Aims:
This module aims to develop the student’s creativity as a lighting designer as well as to foster learning of the technical skills associated with lighting design.
Module Content:
Available 2012/2013 Classes convene once a week in a seminar format led by a professional lighting designer with additional practical projects. Throughout the module students will be encouraged to develop an awareness of light through observation of theatre cinema the visual arts and nature. The first part of the module will examine the nature of light and it’s qualities together with the functions of stage lighting the role of lighting in theatre with particular emphasis on the relevance of stage lighting to the theatre director. Students will explore the relationship between Lighting Design and other design elements e.g. costume design set design. The mechanics of stage lighting will be covered in detail to include the principles of electricity optics light sources and theatre lanterns. The second part of the module will concentrate on the principles and mechanics of lighting the stage. Students will learn how to choose lighting instruments calculate lighting angles control light distribution etc. The Stanley McCandless ‘’Method’’ of stage lighting will be examined in detail together with it’s relevance to modern stage lighting.

Lighting professionals who have previously participated in this course will be brought in to share their experiences and their approach to design.
The role of Automated Lighting will be discussed with practical demonstrations.

name: Comedy And The Comic
description:
Learning Outcomes:
Students should be able to:

demonstrate a working grasp of humour theory and its relevance to text and performance

articulate primary theoretical and philosophical questions regarding the comic in western theatre practice

demonstrate insight into the play and texture of genre with regard to comedy and the comic and key historical incarnations

demonstrate an increased awareness of the potential political currents at work in and between the lines of a comic text and through comic performance

identify common comic strategies on the page of a dramatic text as well as the historical practical possibilities they tend to generate

engage in thoughtful critical analysis of the manners in which contemporary stage film television video and non-dramatic performance have appropiated and exploited comic practices.


 
Module Learning Aims:
This module intends to supply students with a theoretical grasp of the process by which comic text gives way to comic practice in performance. This project leads to an exploration of form and theatre practice over the course of western theatre and into contemporary implications for stage screen television and video. The module also will engage with issues of comedy and the comic with regard to performance genre and politics in the past and present.

 
Module Content:
Available 2012/2013. Classes meet once a week for two hours and will be comprised of theoretical and historical exploration always with an eye upon practice.

Lectures readings seminar discussion response papers classroom presentations.

name: Principles Of Directing
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students should be able to:

conceive and work toward theatricalisation of a concept based on a dramatic text

identify and work with actors toward a realisation of objectives in a text

conceptualise action scenically

arrange and populate the stage space with an eye toward signification

choose appropriate dramaturgical strategies for embodiment

utilise techniques for the motivation of actors

identify textual and character trajectories and work with actors toward their realisation 


 
Module Learning Aims:
This is the first module of a three-part cycle designed to equip students with the skills of the theatre director. This first part of the module will offer a practical engagement with the role of the theatre director and her/his relationship with a text in a workshop environment. The discipline of directing will be considered in turns as an interpretive a pragmatic and a creative art.

 
Module Content:
This module is primarily practical in nature and students should come to class prepared for practical work and with any supplementary reading covered. Throughout the module students should be prepared to present work and to comment critically upon each others work. In the final week of the module each student will direct and present in class a ten-minute scene (duologue) from a text of their own choosing. All text choices must be approved by the module tutor. The module operates throughout the first semester in a series of workshop classes. This course focuses on some of the more fundamental aspects of drama. Looking individually at composition rhythm stages convention subtext articulation play and stage properties the course asks at all times: what is it in each of these things that we find interesting? What is dramatic? And how does that effect our decisions as a director? A certain amount of time and space in these classes will be allotted for demonstration and/or practical engagement with the exercises methodologies and approaches raised in class-time.

name: Applied Drama And Community
description:
Learning Outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this module students should be able to:

 
·     document analyse and evaluate practice as observed in the field

·     research and compare particular aspects of Applied Theatre practice in order to contextualise their placement

·     write a reflective portfolio on of their experiences

 
Module Learning Aims:
This module is the second of three and is designed as an observational work placement of the growing field of drama and theatre practice known as Applied Theatre or Socially-engaged Theatre.

The aim of this second level of the module is that students undertake a study of Applied Theatre in action as a participant observer of a group or project led by an experienced practitioner and evaluate these experiences within the context of a developed knowledge and understanding of the field. 

 
Module Content:
The course centres on a placement to be negotiated by the student in which the student observes the work of an experienced drama/ theatre facilitator. As a participant-observer the student may be invited to assist the project leader or to simply participate as a member of the group.

Fieldwork small-group discussion and reflection and reflective journaling form the core teaching and learning strategies.

(Note: approval for the placement must be given by the course tutor in advance of it taking place.)

name: Stage Design
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students should be able to:

conceive and realise theatrical set-design concepts based on dramatic texts

apply principles of arrangement and signification to stage space

conduct appropriate research with regard to stage design

conceive and build a model box

articulate a design concept for practical realisation


 
Module Learning Aims:
This module aims to foster the student’s creativity as a theatre designer as well as to support learning of the technical skills associated with stage design. The module culminates in the realisation of stage designs for three playtexts in the form of model boxes.

 
Module Content:
Twice-weekly classes will introduce students to the basic skills of the stage designer as well as introducing students to the practicalities of design scale models and use of materials. Inspiration for individual design work by students will be taken from prescribed playtexts and the process will be supervised continually by the module tutor.

The Stage Design room on the top floor of 191 Pearse Street is dedicated to this module and the student is expected to work outside class times. At the end of the first semester there will be a small assessment to check design progress. By the middle of the second semester three design projects will be in progress. Two of these projects will be seen to completion and then all projects will be assessed

name: Theatre And Ireland 1
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students should be able to:

demonstrate knowledge of Irish playwrights and related historical and cultural contexts through the mid-twentieth century

demonstrate knowledge of themes traits and tropes emerging in Irish theatre during the period

analyse and interrogate notions of ‘Irishness’ and cultural identity as represented in Irish theatre with regard to a range of theoretical and political approaches


 
Module Learning Aims:
This module introduces a range of Irish plays and practices from the Melodrama of Dion Boucicault up to the mid-twentieth century. The module explores the founding of the Irish Literary Theatre (ILT) at the turn of the twentieth century and plays by Lady Gregory W.B. Yeats J.M. Synge G.B. Shaw Oscar Wilde Sean O’Casey Teresa Deevy and Mairead Ni Ghrada. The module considers the plays in the light of diverse cultural political and historical contexts relating to gender sexuality class nation colonialism and post-colonialism.

 
Module Content:
The module is composed of a series of weekly one-hour lectures and seminars. A number of plays are covered each week with prescribed critical readings. Lectures explore the plays in-depth as well as the socio-political and cultural climates of the time. Weekly seminars allow for discussion of the plays and the themes and issues that they raise.

name: Theatre And Ireland 2
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students should be able to:

demonstrate knowledge of Irish playwrights and related historical and cultural contexts from the latter twentieth century through the early twenty-first century

demonstrate knowledge of themes traits and tropes emerging in Irish theatre during the period

analyse and interrogate notions of ‘Irishness’ and cultural identity as represented in Irish theatre with regard to a range of theoretical socio-cultural and political approaches


 
Module Learning Aims:
This module introduces students to the major playwrights of Irish theatre from Samuel Beckett to Marina Carr. The module explores a number of recent and contemporary companies such as Field Day Charabanc and Operating Theatre. Students will study the work of Samuel Beckett Brian Friel Tom Murphy Frank McGuinness Anne Devlin Christina Reid Tom Kilroy Mark O’Rowe Stella Feehily Martin McDonagh and Marina Carr. The module will consider key works within socio-cultural contexts as well as their histories of production and reception.

 
Module Content:
The module is composed of a series of lectures and seminars. A number of plays are covered each week with prescribed critical readings. Lectures explore the plays in-depth as well as the socio-political and cultural contexts of the time. Seminars allow for discussion of the plays and the themes and issues that they raise. Class will view DVD and VTR interview and film footage through-out the semester during the lecture.

name: American Drama
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On completion of this module students should be able to demonstrate:

Awareness of historical geographic economic and political conditions affecting American Drama

Contextual awareness of major playwrights critical tradition and aesthetic theories of the 20th and early 21st centuries in the US

Ability to analyze and contextualize dramatic texts from the US

Expanded awareness of complexity of identity representation particularly in the US context

 
Module Learning Aims:
This is a one-term course in Hilary Term that focuses on the canonical work of some of the major figures in American playwriting in the twentieth century. The focus of the course will be on the ways that these playwrights have represented aspects of national and cultural identity. We will read and discuss playtexts and will consult supplementary readings for context and criticism.
Module Content:
This course runs for 12 weeks in Hilary Term with weekly two-hour seminar classes moving through course content in approximately chronological order. Readings for each week will include one to two plays (frequently in dialogue with one another) in addition to historical theoretical and/or critical selections. Classes will include presentations on theatrical movements playwrights etc. followed by guided discussion of the themes and issues involved in each week’s readings. Issues raised weekly will be considered in a comparative context over the whole of the year. Students will be expected to prepare one- to two-page typed responses to readings regularly as well as to prepare one class presentation on a chosen topic during the semester.

name: Acting
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students should be able to:

demonstrate a core sense of honest behaviour under the given conditions thrown up by a written text

demonstrate a dual sense of engagement with a scene partner and the fictional conditions both in thrall to the here-and-now of performance

demonstrate an abiding sense of the kind of freedom in performance that comes from effective rehearsal

access a provisional template for reading and analysing a text and exploring its dramatic potential

demonstrate an awareness of the technical demands for body voice and space in making the stage world accessible to the spectator

embody a professional-calibre work ethic in terms of personal reliability and ensemble commitment


 
Module Learning Aims:
This is a studio module in the establishment of a personal acting technique primarily as regards exploration and rehearsal of dramatic text toward a present and crafted performance. Each student works toward the self-driven rehearsal and performance of a series of scenes and monologues. 

 
Module Content:
This module is a workshop-based acting class for which vital learning takes place in the studio. As a result full attendance and unflagging commitment are essential. At the same time there is a strong emphasis on the actor’s responsibility to work outside class. Although theoretical texts about acting will be referred to along the way there are no formal reading assignments aside from plays – constant reflection and analysis is encouraged through regular class discussion and written engagement. The module begins with a series of exercises improvisations and assignments designed to instil a sense of spontaneous engagement and simple truth to behaviour under fictional circumstances. In a beginning round of scene work students are led through the process of reading a text as an actor plumbing and exploring the text through a two-pronged attention to organic behaviour and rooted readable performance. While students receive personal attention and insight into the actor’s toolbox throughout the process they are also expected to take personal responsibility for the scene’s growth rehearsing without supervision and putting in work outside of class. A written assignment in the form of a log-like reflection on practice and process is due at the end of each semester. Attention will also be given to the use of voice and body in the rehearsal process. Students are required to take both semesters of the module but those who demonstrate insufficient commitment face exclusion after the first semester.

name: Women In The Theatre
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students should be able to:

demonstrate knowledge of key plays by women dramatists performance artists and feminist and lesbian theatre groups

display an awareness of the complexities of feminisms the history of gender sexuality and the body

demonstrate an ability to apply diverse feminist and queer theories to theatrical and cultural contexts


 
Module Learning Aims:
This module introduces students to a selection of women playwrights performance artists and lesbian and feminist political theatre. Students will consider issues of gender sexuality and embodiment in cultural historical and theatrical contexts in the light of feminist and queer theories. Additionally students will interrogate the politics of canon-formation and gendered issues of authorship and representation as well as the theoretical and practical developments of Feminism(s) in relation to the history of women in theatre and contemporary practice. Playwrights explored are Marina Carr Simone Benmussa Eve Ensler Sarah Daniels Paula Vogel Sarah Kane and Caryl Churchill and performance artists Orlan Carolee Schneeman and Holly Sprinkle as well as feminist theatre group the Guerrilla Girls on Tour and lesbian theatre companies WOW Split Britches and the raunch culture of new burlesque. Popular culture and media will also be discussed including ‘pot-feminism’ and the third-wave feminism of ‘Sex and the City’. Students will analyse plays and performance-pieces in the light of contemporary feminist criticism and theories of performance by Elin Diamond Peggy Phelan Elaine Aston Sue Ellen Case and French feminist theory among others. 

 
Module Content:
This module is composed of a series of weekly two-hour sessions. The first hour of the session consists of a lecture and the second hour is an exploratory interactive seminar/work-shop. A number of plays are explored every week in addition to prescribed theoretical and critical readings. Students frame the plays in short presentations during the work-shop hour and explore the texts through group scene-work and open discussion. Each week is regarded as an ongoing continuation of explorations into gender politics female subjectivity and feminism(s) and students are encouraged to think holistically and reflexively throughout the nine-weeks. Productions images (PowerPoint) video and DVD footage are shown in the first hour.

name: Playwriting
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students should be able to:

demonstrate an awareness of skills necessary to an understanding of dramatic effectiveness

demonstrate an understanding of how to evaluate a playwriting work in progress

assess what questions best serve to help explore the inner workings of a play

recognize when a piece of dramatic text or performance is not working why and what direction might next be taken

write a short play


 
Module Learning Aims:
This module will give students the opportunity to develop their own playwriting skills by working in stages towards completing a one-act play. They will explore some elements of dramatic theory in relation to plays read seen and heard in class. The overall aim is to build confidence in assessing what makes plays work and to enable students to transfer skills learnt in class to the complex process of dramatic writing. 

 
Module Content:
Semester one: 

Students will read and discuss set works of dramatic theory and dramatic texts. They will read and then see a play in performance. They will complete an essay and six short writing exercises.

Semester two: 

Students will read each other's work in class and learn the methodology of play workshops.

Students meet once a week for two hours over two semesters. Students will be allocated reading in advance of each workshop for discussion in class in the first semester. During this semester students will also be required to complete one 1500 word essay on dramatic theory from an assigned text or on an assigned play and six short dramatic writing exercises. Some of these will also be read in class for discussion. In the second semester excerpts from the students’ own plays in progress will be read by the class each week and then discussed. The emphasis in the second semester is on hearing work and developing the ability to critique what is heard in a constructive way. The student can then learn to internalise this process to help with their own writing.

name: Advanced Acting
description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students should be able to:

incorporate an abiding sense of organic behaviour rooting even the most extravagant performance styles

demonstrate a continued sense of engagement with a scene partner and the fictional conditions both in thrall to the here-and-now of performance

maintain an appreciation for the importance of research particularly with regard to historical texts

demonstrate an expansion of the basic template for reading and analysing a text and exploring its dramatic potential especially as material inclines away from the contemporary and naturalistic

demonstrate an increased grasp of the technical demands for body voice and space in making the stage world accessible to the spectator

demonstrate a continued instilment of a professional-calibre work ethic in terms of personal reliability and ensemble commitment

demonstrate a further wherewithal to oversee one’s progress as an actor in life after acting class


 
Module Learning Aims:
This module follows on from the Acting module to engrain and build upon rehearsal philosophies for the approach of more challenging historical texts. It is a studio module in the advanced cultivation of a personal acting technique primarily as regards exploration and rehearsal of dramatic text toward a present and crafted performance. The demands on the student increase at this level to include research and analysis as well as more difficult and diverse material. Class meets for two hours per week with students obliged to undertake the bulk of rehearsal (two to four hours) outside formal class time.

 
Module Content:
This module is a workshop-based acting class for which vital learning takes place in the studio. As a result full attendance and unflagging commitment are essential. At the same time there is a strong emphasis on the actor’s responsibility to think research and rehearse outside of class. There are no formal reading assignments aside from chosen plays – but a far greater emphasis will be placed on work done outside class including rehearsal research and analytical engagement. A failure to give suitable priority to the demands of the module during first semester may result in exclusion for the second semester. Advanced exercises and games will be used to further stretch the performer’s senses of organic connection and spontaneity however the focus of the module remains upon the process of rehearsal. Further attention will be given to the technical demands of voice and body with increasing responsibility placed upon the student to develop an awareness of the instrument its capabilities and obligations. Increased focus will be placed on the performer’s responsibility to research text and reflect upon process.

 
Class work over two semesters will focus on a succession of scenes addressing the stylistic demands of tragedy comedy and their various historical permutations as well as Shakespearean verse and monologue/soliloquy

name: European Cinema
description:
Learning Outcomes:
Module Learning Aims:
Module Content:
This course will look at and examine the changes taking place in cinema in Europe in the latter part of the twentieth century and the beginning of the twenty-first. This was a period that saw enormous transformation throughout the continent - both East and West – when the post World War II political dispensation collapsed and Cold War divisions crumbled. The fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991 and the subsequent overthrow of the remaining Stalinist regimes in Eastern & Central Europe the emergence of the European Union as a transnational political entity in 1992 and the globalization of the world economy all impacted on the way in which films were made and the type of themes they explored and topics they tackled.

description:
Learning Outcomes:
On successful completion of this module students will be able to:

·     Plan prepare and shoot a documentary film

·     Identify the story deciding an angle or view-point and the journalistic approach

·     Use cameras and audio equipment in the field

·     Understand the language of documentary and different styles of documentary filmmaking

·     Interview subjects in a professional manner

·     Construct a narrative and prepare for an edit

 
Module Learning Aims:
This practical module is designed to give students a basic understanding of the processes of developing scripting planning shooting and selling a documentary film. It will concentrate on the practical aspects of documentary filmmaking and the inherent issues and problems. It will provide students with the audio and camera skills required to document a subject. We will look at the problem of access: how to get it and what it means. How to treat your subject conduct interviews and chose a style for your work and how to successfully realise your project. We will look at planning and scripting and how best to pick a style that suits your subject needs. In addition we will have camera classes where students will be taught the basics of filming real life scenes. Students will be required to come up with ideas for a short form documentary 5 minutes in duration and set on the grounds of TCD. Classes will be organised around a practical format working first through a series of exercises and then taking these projects through to completion.

 
Methods of Teaching and Student Learning

Teaching methods will include lectures screening of relevant extracts and practical class exercises. Students will be required to generate ideas for a short form documentary. The class will be split into crews and these projects will be taken from the planning and development stages to final filming and preparation for edit. As we enter each stage of development students will be given the skills required paying special attention to the problems that arise on each project and how best to solve them.

 
Module Content:
Basic concepts of documentary: what is a documentary film?

Treatments: what do I want to say and how best to say it?

Planning what is the documentary style? 

How to prepare a shoot.

How to write a script

An understanding of shots scenes and the vocabulary of film.

How to film in a real life setting (fly-on-the-wall).

Problem solving in the field.

How to conduct interviews and put your subject at ease.

How to prepare for an edit with a paper edit.

Writing voice over and narration.

In this module students will explore analyze and theorize the structures and amateur potentials of such digital storyworlds and create their own digital storyworlds such as video essays and desktop documentaries.

Methods of Teaching and Learning:

Teaching methods include lectures seminar discussions and critical discussions of students’ transmedia artifacts. Classes will be a combination of lecture seminar written theoretical and analytical exercises and digital practice exercises such as video essays and desktop documentaries. Students will be expected to attend all classes and screenings read from primary as well as secondary sources comment upon the readings and participate in class discussion. Additionally students will be required to produce written theoretical and analytical as well as practically based digital coursework. Students will be given the option of working in groups to develop their practical work in the course.
Module Content:
Module content:

This module approaches digital storyworlds from theoretical as well as practical perspectives. We will theorize the impact of digital technologies on storytelling discuss a range of issue including transmedia storytelling network aesthetics mind-game narratives the politics of low-resolution imagery and the aesthetic potentials of amateur and “prosumer” digital production. We will also consider how contemporary cultures of amateur production such as video essays and desktop documentaries fit into a longer history of experimentation with the possibilities and limits of new mediums from the avant-gardes up to the present.

Learning outcomes:

an understanding of the working practice of the acting process

ability to translate inner feelings to characterisation

ability to liberate the imagination to explore character and scene

ability to interpret the use of verse in classical texts

an understanding of the relationship between character and a credible fictional world

ability to research as part of the actor’s preparation

ability to present research and communicate ideas within a rehearsal context


 
Module Learning Aims:
Module Content:
This module will introduce students to a range of acting techniques necessary for the performance of both realist and classical texts. It has three inter-related components (the Method of Konstantin Stanislavski applied to the Realist plays of the historical avant garde; an introduction to the performance of Classical Texts focusing on the language structure metre sound and meaning of Shakespeare’s language; an Introduction to twentieth-century Irish and British playwriting with a view to the development of research and presentation skills as part of an actor’s preparation).

description:

Learning outcomes:

to develop an introductory knowledge of vocal technique and physiology

to connect physical alignment with vocal production

to develop sight-reading abilities for professional contexts

to develop a practical understanding of phonetic recognition and notation as well as vocal production

to construct and actor’s singing repertoire


 
Module Learning Aims:
Module Content:
This module aims to develop an understanding of the imaginative impulse emanating from text and how it connects to the form of language through voice. It features classes in vocal anatomy breathing techniques the use of play and physical action in vocal production. Along with classes in technique students in sight-reading classes will learn systems of approaching text from the point of view of style rhythm and period. Furthermore students will be trained in transcribing dialect phonetically enabling them to study accent beyond vowel and consonant substitution. Special attention will be paid to Irish and British accents including RP. Further in choral and individual singing classes students will develop basic musicianship understand musical notation and free the natural voice through song.

description:

to develop imaginative transformations through physical embodiment

to develop a tangible relationship between the body and space

to understand and develop the vocabulary of movement in the establishment of social relations in performance

to develop an ability to sustain character in formal movement including dance and stage combat.

To acquire skills in improvisation to enable character and scene creativity

To develop an alignment of body voice and the creative imagination

 

 
Module Learning Aims:
Module Content:
This module aims to develop an understanding of movement as a vehicle for the discovery of physical psychological and emotional life of characters their motivations and actions. It also aims to develop a practical understanding of movement within interpersonal and social relations in spatial environments and to develop an actor’s movement vocabulary in styles forms and systems including the Laban technique. Workshops in improvisation are aimed to develop an actor’s theatrical creativity by the exclusive use of the imagination through play. Classes in social dance and stage combat expand the movement repertoire of the actor and seek to develop and perform a movement vocabulary style rhythm form and formation. Individual tutorials in Alexander Technique complement the Movement Studies outlined above with the aim of developing and sustaining the actor’s body through kinaesthetic awareness.

Module Learning Aims:

Module Content:
CORE MODULE: The module begins with an introduction to music computing on a digital audio workstation. Students are introduced to MIDI sequencers scores and software instruments.
